I used to believe that I was the one in control of my life, thatI was responsible whether I have a good career, a decent home and a decent position in the social hierarchy. Watching videos like this made me realize how most of what I have today wasn't because of me but was because of the thousands of years of humanity's progress. There had been roughly 100 billion humans that ever existed 90 billion of them now dead. No matter where they're from, what culture they had, what timeline they existed. They laughed, they loved, they had families, friends, enemies, they had fears, they had their dreams. No matter which timeline, culture, society, or technology any of us and those before us, there were always those constant things that always stayed and defined us as humans. Every convenience, technology, food, ubiquitous things, the smallest of things that no one ever appreciates anymore like the phone you're probably using right now, these were all a result of process that took thousands of years through humanity's journey.

If we are fair, why the world adopted agriculture is not really a mystery and it is very evident that a lot of people did not "voluntarily choose" the sedentary farmer's civilization nor consider it superior to the nomadic one. What stationary agriculture enabled for those who adopted it was to support a far larger population - a vital ingredient in warfare and conquest - to impose their doctrine and take the land of those that did not. The plains Indians of N.America, for example, believed that the land, the water, the buffalo were the collective asset of the tribe. The concept of land being fenced off as individual "private property" farms was a ghastly abomination to them.

We don't have to go back to Mesopotamian pre-history. As recently as 800 years ago, most of the world's landmass was not ruled by people who bought into the agricultural revolution concept. The aforementioned Indians of N. America, the Australian Aborigines, the herders of Africa, and the largest empire in Euroasia was that of the semi-nomadic Mongols.

We might even be able to change our fate which the dinosaurs couldn't.

There's no mistery at all in the issue: stability. It was easier to guarantee the food, easier to keep a solid shelter in which you would invest more resources and time and therefore not leave it just behind. In exchange, more security, a prevision on possible climate changes, the possibility of a larger community, better defence. Any species try to maximize their chances and stability is always a good way of doing so. In this case it is obvious it was easier to grow and to defend, so these communities survived most, in opposition to others.

The thing I find absolutely incredible is that humans existed for nearly 2 million years, then all of a sudden ~10000-20000 years ago, agriculture developed simultaneously, independently, in multiple places in the world. Sure, you could blame the end of the ice age, but we'd lived through more than one of those already. Why only this time did they build up enough to leave behind ruins and artifacts? Not only that, but it happened independently in multiple places, forming civilizations like Mesopotamia, Ancient Egypt, China, Indus River Valley, and Norte Chico? As far as we know, those civilizations had no cross-communication, so what else could have caused this to happen?

The human era started less than 10,000 years ago. That is according to the most accurate history book we have from the beginning of the Earth and all life.
And that is eyewitness evidence, not made up fairy tales for high school students. And we wonder why our kids act like animals when they are taught that they are just animals.

This is a theory put together by Darwin. Remember the finches on the Galapagos Islands? Darwin said that they evolved all these species of finches, which were just finches, and that they had speciated in 2.3 million years.
Now how in the heck did he figure that out? Based on what evidence?

Now we know. There was no evidence whatsoever. Now we know from a recent experiment that put a group of finches, all the same species, on a remote island. And guess what?
17 years later they came back to find that the finches had speciated into many different species of finch.

So what is the evolutionist to do? It is obvious that there was quick speciation in the finches. It proves that finches, like every other organism on Earth has the ability to vary according to the niche it will fit into. Whether dogs or cats or finches, all kinds of animal are programmed to vary according to their environment.

No evolution needed, thank you very much.

I wish you also would have brought up the downsides that came with the agricultural revolution and our transition from being hunter-gatherers. Before the revolution we lived in highly egalitarian tribes, both between people in general but also between men and women. We were healthier, cooperated more etc. After the revolution 10000 years ago, hierarchy was invented and with it also patriarchy, slavery and wars etc. seems like in some ways things were better the way we lived for almost 200000 years. Obviously we built civilizations and we should be grateful for the progress our ancestors achieved, but our hunter-gatherer ancestors should definitely be admired for their better and more peaceful qualities. Likewise in the future, our descendants should be grateful to us but also criticize us for the destruction we have brought.
the most probable answer for the reason humans started farming was because it was a guaranteed food source

The first Agricultural Revolution was the worst move humanity ever made. The hunter/gatherers lived a much more fulfilling life. It is estimated they only "worked" three days out of seven, had a rich and varied diet and were virtually disease free. They lived in a real version of the garden of Eden.
Religion was invented to govern and socially control the newly created concentration of humans. Accountants were created to keep track of food production which lead to local power structures and warfare.
Just about everything that is wrong in the modern world can be traced back to the development of agriculture and yet we are sold the lie that it was a "good" thing.

These videos are great, and they provide a massive amount of information in condensed, easy to follow animations. However, this completely skipped over two of the most important factors of human civilization: the role of religion and the effects of warfare. Humans are not (yet) a completely cooperative species, and we have rarely behaved as rationally as this video seems to suggest. Why trade a life of freedom and diverse diet for a sedentary life of toil? There were probably many reasons, but let's not forget that one of the main reasons was probably because "the sun god wants you to, and I know this because I am the sun god's prophet, so you should listen to me. Also, the god of the rain wants us to brutally conquer that other settlement over there."

Cus my thinking is that we're in the age of advanced communication now. We can store, preserve, and pass on info better than we could ever. We can even compress our info onto tiny usbs, compared to books. And even with books and paintings, we've learned so much about events from the last few 1000 years. We know that we went through the plague, built castles, and about some guy named spartacus. Then writing became more advanced because of the print and press and typewriters, so now we still can read a book written in the 1700 - 1800s.
So as long as we continue to update, preserve, and protect our data libraries, museums, or info, the future shouldn't really have oodles to dig for. Unless you think that's more fun.

Unless there was a revolution in the field in the three years since I graduated the consensus I saw was that it wasn't a deliberate choice but a result of climate change, namely the younger dryas (not for each time it emerged, but for the Levant at least), which was a sort of tail whip after the last ice age when temperatures, that had risen steadily over the years, dropped suddenly by a few degrees. The cold reduces the number of plants which in turn reduces animals, the human hunter-gatherers that feed on both need to resort to less efficient and care-intensive foods like grains.

You even cite later how the switch to agriculture had populations malnourished, why would someone purposely change their entire way of life to do something that is less nourishing and more time-intensive than what they do now if they don't have to due to external constraints?

Recommending an interesting topic for your team to consider making into a video: the multiple competitions among germ cells that lead to the final egg-sperm pairing. Egg cells compete to be ovulated (a little-known topic called ovarian follicular dominance, here's a nice review: Baker SJ, Spears N. The role of intra-ovarian interactions in the regulation of follicle dominance. Hum Reprod Update. 1999 Mar-Apr;5(2):153-65. doi: 10.1093/humupd/5.2.153. PMID: 10336019). Sperm also compete, as most people know, but there also appears to be a process of selection between the egg and sperm as well - not all eggs and sperm are attracted to one another. It's a fascinating topic, I think it would make it a good video.

You guys are usually very good, but your Whig history / pro "technological" "progress" bias is showing -- discussing the rise of agriculture without discussing the rise of conquering states and their forcible integration or genocide of non-agrarian groups, is basically not discussing it at all. It's certainly true that the first cities were voluntarily organized, cooperative, and possibly democratic -- but the fact that those sacred temple-cities soon came under the authoritarian rule of priest-kings, and that the imperialistic conquests of these were the main way agrarian/urban lifestyles were to spread thereafter, is not particularly controversial. That is a much less inspiring story, but it's one we need to grapple with if we're to make the word "civilization" something actually minimally decent rather than a catalogue of disguised barbarisms.

Wouldn't the decision to settle down also be somewhat of a chain reaction? If one nomadic tribe decides to settle down, they claim a portion of land for themselves. A lot of the polarization in the US at least (I am not sure about in other countries) is because our fortified foods have 10x as much calcium as magnesium.  This has caused widespread soft tissue calcification for many people, including in their brain.  This is a normal process, but it is happening faster because of the huge imbalance between calcium and magnesium in our foods.  Some people have differences in how their body processes calcium that also worsens this effect.  Artificial Vitamin D supplementation can cause calcification to accumulate faster as well.  When parts of your brain calcify, it can be impossible to think clearly or to balance multiple conflicting priorities and perspectives at once, causing stubbornness and aggression.  This calcification literally reverses itself once you start consuming enough magnesium!  If legislation were passed that required fortified foods to contain calcium and magnesium in proper proportion, the polarization in the US would decrease significantly within just one generation.  The less magnesium you consume, the more toxic calcium is.  Taking a high dose of calcium is actually HORRIBLE for your bones, NOT good for it.  You MUST consume about as much magnesium.  Otherwise, you will wreck both your bones and your soft tissue.  I know all this because I lived all of it.

Why? why do we keep working for the future? why do we do what we do? why do we even work for our survival? WHAT'S THE POINT OF IT ALL?
so far nothing, no answer, we're just born into a world with no answers to critical question. People often question religion and get a vague answer, and question the meaning of existence and receive a vague answer.
It feels as if humans are living in a petri dish or a terrarium, we are limited by our world perception that we cant perceive anything beyond it. A scary thought comes to mind, if I were a character in an advanced simulation made especially for me, how would I know? and even if I know, what do I do with this information? is there even a point in asking these questions? if there is no point to my curious question, then there is no point in doing anything.

I often try and ponder these questions with family and friends, but they either make fun of me or avoid engaging in conversation, I don't think they understand my thought process, and I dont blame them. Loneliness is a harsh mistress, and pain is it's only companion.

Once again, great video, vielen dank Kurzgesagt!
I'm not so sure about two points: the common theme in many of your videos about humanity's space expansion and the concept of gratitude in an historical observation.

You often present an interest and hope in space travel and colonisation. While I believe space studies are a field to absolutely keep on furthering our knowledge in, we have many more problems to study and solve on Earth. We should keep our view wide but optimised on VERY urgent matters (large things like economics, politics, POLLUTION AND GLOBAL WARMING, how to defend society from bad leaders and capital owners, etc.).
And on a VERY personal note, I would not want to expand human influence and problems outside before we have not even learned to manage ourselves on this planet.
I could see the argument that space travel might give hope of a better future for humanity (maybe like in the 1960's and 70's) or that it would open doors for us that might help us improve in a better society. But speculating, it could also continue as it is (which I find alarming, just my opinion) or worse.
I'm putting in an ethical and moral perspective, but I think it's a factor to consider among the others and that we are abandoning ourselves to developments (mostly technologicals) without posing the question "Looks like we could do it. SHOULD we do it?"

It's heartwarming hearing your comments about learning from our past and keeping in mind the efforts of our ancestors, but I find the sense of GRATITUDE misplaced when the point is observing history.
It should not be a cold science, but the fact is that we are observing HOW things went (or speculate with our scarce data left by the eons) and should not judge if it was good or bad, right or wrong. Or not make it the direct point of the studies, at least. That should be a later discussion when taking decisions in the present.
Our ancestors might even have hugely screwed up and of the many possible outcomes we got the worse ones. Who knows! I'm grateful for their efforts and findings, but I think that when dealing with History it can be a very delicate matter to nurrish these kind of feelings. We rewrote history many times on the basis of ideologies of the time, which is dangerous or at the very least complicates our studies. And also, even with the many things I might be grateful for, humanity has also chosen rather dark paths many times and the consequences have very negative effects to this day.

Once more, thanks for the content!

We won't stop climate change. It's a fact. On a brighter side, at least Antarctica will grow rainforests, so I wouldn't worry too much about it. The thing about climate change is that the change is so slow it's negligible to human lifetime. If you are born today, the average temperature will be less than one degree higher when you hit your 80th birthday. A hardly noticeable change for you.
For the planet, sure, in 1000 years from now everything but Antarctica, Alaska, New Zealand, Greenland, Iceland, Canada and Syberia will be a desert, that is if we continue pumping CO2 which I highly doubt. We'll stop pumping it in about 200 years from now, so again, nothing to worry about. Kurzgesagt is alarmist because that's the tactic their side of the lobby uses. The other side of the lobby will tell you there is no climate change. The truth is really in the middle. There is climate change, it does harm our way of life, but not to the extent argued in this video and it will resolve before the Earth is turned into Dune. In truth, we have far bigger problems ahead of us.

A bit of an oversimplification though that isn't unexpected for these sorts of things. There is evidence however that human congregations at least in the case of the Tigris Euphrates and the Nile river systems seems to have been more  or less driven by environmental shifts than anything else.  People otherwise seemed to have lived in family groups or tribes until they were forced to change in what was probably a discontinuous process that occurred for different reasons in different places. Large colonies formed earlier during the Neolithic perhaps related to the sea level rise that had been ongoing as the planet but they fell apart at least in one case likely thanks to the adaptation of a food born illness into the veritable scourge known as Y. Pestis.   Agriculture and herding played a huge role in the drastic acceleration from the wet phase of Africa and the middle east/Arabian peninsula which occurred at a drastically accelerated rate of centuries rather than the normal transition period of a few thousand years. This was unequivocally tied to the extensive archaeological evidence of widespread pastoral herders in the area overgrazing the Sahara triggering desertification to more rapidly drive the transition. As the grasslands and savannas  and eventually most of the rivers dried up into barren desert humans were effectively forced to migrate to the few rivers that hadn't dried us the Tigris Euphrates watershed fed from the mountains and the Nile feed from the Ethiopian highlands and the continental interior. After a stark period of violence with little records remaining of what happened exactly only then did the first true densely populated cities and civilizations arise in the Mediterranean region. I suspect similar stories are probably behind the rise of civilizations elsewhere being spurred by the precessional shifts of the Earth's orbit. From this story unraveled from sediment records and archaeological evidence revealing this one instance I wouldn't be surprised if much of change in human history was  forced on us by circumstances.

One thing is left out of all of this, is the human longing to be aggressive, wage war, and punch someone else and take what belongs to them so they won't have to work for it. That is why people started living together when they could, built towns with wooden walls, then cities with stone walls, and armies, creating the need for better crops. Because you can never forget that humans thrive off of strife. Give humans plenty of food and drink and they'll do nothing but sit and eat and gripe about how bad they have it. Just look at America today! But put a problem in front of them, an invading army, a war, a disaster, a famine, and they come together to solve that problem. It's that problem solving is what created pretty much all progress in humankind and got is where we are today. Humans aren't peaceful beings who long to live together. They do so out of necessity, out of fear, a concept that was lacking in this entire presentation apart from the very beginning where we 'might' have 'helped' to make other human-type races extinct.

I would argue that the human era started when humans became a valid species, I.E. when humans evolved. Those humans that put ground up animal fats in bone tubes to spray around their children's hands were happy. They had enough of a happy life to put hours of labor into playing with their children. I'd say the age you describe is instead, the age of the crafting humans. When we got more and more obsessed with farming and building and tool-making and more, and forgot our simple, happy roots.

Few parents have spare hours to play with their children nowadays, bogged down by a job and ground under the powerful metaphorical grindstone that is modern society, just because the rich are lazy and greedy enough to overstress their workers without thought of how it might hurt them. All because humans shoved themselves together and didn't worry about how bitter it made them, putting bread over emotions and using that bread as an excuse to keep doing so. Until humanity can bring themselves to get off their buts and use technology to aid ALL of humanity, not just the rich and semi-rich, then we'll never get to have hours upon hours to play with our families. And THAT'S the lesson you should take away from that lifestyle.

Perhaps one of the reasons the switch was made to large scale farming, was because crops would be eaten by animals unless tended to. So while early humans planted seeds and returned to them at a later date, some would find that they had already been eaten by grazing animals, and would have problems with food in areas where they depended on the crops. So they eventually decided to settle next to their farms, perhaps only a few at a time from a tribe, until there were enough crops to remain year round.

I wonder what the world would be like if we had never stopped being nomads. If instead of making fields, we would have allowed nature to thrive. How much more diversity of food, landscapes and cultures would there be? How much more freedom? And would the planet have been able to support the number of people we have now? Or would our population have remained much smaller, more proportionate to the rest of the world? Whenever I walk through a forest, I think how much more fun and interesting life could be, if you could still choose to live like a nomad and just travel through endless landscapes and gather food in nature instead of working and living in cities. It seems crazy to me, that there is not enough nature left in most countries that you could choose to be an independent nomad and live off nature  instead. That there are borders everywhere, no places that do not belong to anybody, where people could just live simple lives and be allowed to hunt and gather or just build a little house for themselves and just exist without having to pay rent and taxes. That nowadays you have pretty much no choice but live as part of a society and make money, so you can pay for a little spot to live and a share of food, that your ancestors could just gather, hunt and build for free.

Though humans seem as if we have progressed so much, its actually not a lot. Think of it like this. Homo Sapiens have existed for the past 1.8 million years. About 20,000 years ago, the Agricultural Revolution began. We are absolutely not "Exponentially Growing." We are growing faster as the Industrial Revolution began 220 years ago. After that we created computers in 1822, known as a Difference Engine. It weighed tons and was the size of an entire room. It could perform simple math problems and could print using over 25,000 parts. We sent a person to moon in 1969, and already had Yuri Gagarin enter space earlier. We are progressing in the space sector, and many people are joining this interesting change in humanity.  In about 10,000 years we may be fully taking use of the resources of the terrestrial planets and moons in the solar system. It is hard to make an assumption but the practice of being a historian may be nearly entirely dominated by machines. If robots can do a job much faster and cleaner than humans, then that would mean that people would still enjoy seeing wonders from the past, maybe even everyday items for us. At this time it could be harder to study history as we would be in multiple places. We may even separate into completely different groups. Let me explain how this logic works. If we stay isolated from one another from long enough, we may not see other people as something similar to ourselves. Of course I could be entirely wrong as progress itself is speeding and becoming harder and harder to predict. Imagine this scenario: In the early 2000's, a Motorola DynaTac costed  $3,900. Now, a iPhone X costs about $999. Imagine the difference. A flip phone and a phone which has 1Terabyte of memory. This just shows, how in under 20 years, we progressed so much. Still don't understand? Then let me explain what I said at the beginning again. Homo Sapiens have existed for 1.8 million years. For 1,780,000 years we had slow progress until the agricultural revolution. Around 12,000 years ago, we formed communities. Around 6,000 years ago, the first empires emerged. About 1,000 years ago, we were able to advance not only our warfare, but also learning skills. We created printing presses, discovered electricity in the 1700's, began the Industrial Revolution in the 1800's, and in a mere 110 years we began aviation. This wasn't enough, so in 69 years we sent a man to the moon. In 31 years, we created phones, and here we are now. Do you see how the time in-between major events keeps getting smaller and smaller? From thinking about the past, we need to think about the future.

To those of the distant future looking back into your past,

I welcome you to our digital record. No doubt you will find in your time a true treasure trove here of both vast knowledge and lives lived and gone. As a generation, we had become fascinated at how technology had changed the way we could live our lives and communicate with one another. Many of us found ourselves into a new world where we could consistently record the little things that counted, and I am sure for those among yourselves with a curious mind, that occurrence has unraveled many of the little questions you wish we were capable of answering.

As exciting as this may be for us, for you, this thing we call the internet is a tool of far greater wonder. You are able to look back in a way no human has ever before been capable of. Perhaps by your own standards, this is all rudimentary technology at best, but with this network being a historical artifact like none other, you are capable of doing what in my own time was impossible: travel into the past. Unlike any time before my present, you are capable of seeing, hearing, and experiencing 'en masse' the whole human experience from those before you. For better or worse, my generation has opened their hearts, minds, and lives to you. I hope you take the time to appreciate the gift in that.

I'm pretty sure the transition from nomadic to sedentary societies was mostly driven by the immense advantage of being able to build more sophisticated dwelling.

Nomadic societies most likely relied in very rudimentary shelters which they could take with them whenever they moved, or had to build new shelters whenever they reached a new location, which would have taken them tons of time and energy. Sedentary societies on the other hand could build actual houses, which gave them better protection against the weather and animals.

What we see as the "freedom of a wild, nomadic existence with plenty of choice in food" was probably constant insecurity and instability and never knowing if you would be able to find your next meal or outrun your predator  to them.

I think there are 3 steps to humanity development. what makes human a unique animal is its ability to learn.
The first step was talking : being able to efficiently teach what you learned, give information, to humans of your generation, and the next generation.
The second step was writing : being able to save information, to stack it, to give it to future generations easily, efficiently.
The third step was internet : being able to share information, on a very large scale, and to access it instantly, any human knowledge.

Each step raised the humanity learning speed. 3rd step actually began with the encyclopedia and printing, but now the information is no longer limited, deteriorated by time or distance, and this is significant. Humanity can’t theoretically learn faster than today, but now robots learn, faster than humans for some tasks, and for more and more tasks. Maybe we just jumped 2 steps at once..

This is only philosophy.
Humanity isn’t that simple.
Yet this is, to me, surprisingly accurate.

Here's to the next 12020 years. And yes we will last that long. But, will we still be a globe spanning species like we are now only better. Or will we be reduced to small isolated civilizations living in a pre-industrial state. That is up to us.
It would take a lot for us to go completely extinct. We are an extremely adaptable species and even if we are reduced to a few groups of 500 + people around the world. That's all it takes.
Our species can even survive the most extreme scenarios if we've prepared for it.

Civilization may end but not humanity.

Pretty sure humans came together in increasingly larger groups to settle (village --> towns) because there is an economy of scale with respect to labour specialisation. e.g. its more efficient to practice as a farmer than be an all-rounder hunter gatherer. The one farmer can feed 10x more people than a hunter could. This allowed others to specialise in things like fighting/defence/arts etc. This along with the greater power/safety in numbers of a larger group of people defending one place, especially if that place had advantages like water, naturally defensible rock formations, access to the sea, good rainfalls etc.

7:13 imagine if they decided to not spread knowledge and gave up, getting back to hunting and shit what would be now. A process that takes so many lives with just for a bigger scope, a scope that even they didn't know yet but was what changes human life forever. If that was really an arbitrary choice, well we are really great, aren't we?

I think it's also important to note that the Agricultural Revolution definitely changed our lives for the better: in a little more than 5,000 years we've gone from using stone tools (and for scale, the Stone Age was approx 3.4 million years long) to being able to essentially communicate instantly with someone on the other side of the planet. This was all because we had enough food so that the best and brightest had the free time to innovate. We may look upon the bloated mess that is the State as a parasite today - and it is - but that framework has also enabled excellence.

We have never been safer or had more ways to waste time doing nothing productive. We should be thankful for the dedication and sacrifices of our forebears to what were, at the time, narrow ambitions and probably wealth amassing goals. At the end of the day, we benefit from both their selfishness and selflessness, whichever may be the case.

Brilliant and fascinating as always, but as a trained professional economist I must take exception to the idea that transitioning from hunter-gatherer lifestyles to agrarian ones is an unexplained mystery. There may not be perfect consensus, but the lack of understanding of this change seems dramatically over-sold as a supposed mystery, here. The explanation almost certainly comes down to simple risk-aversion: Yes, agricultural lifestyles are more toilsome and less diverse, but they are also much, much, much less random. A bad year for an agrarian tribe is much less harrowing than a bad year for hunter-gatherers. Indeed most economists believe that this very moment of transition explains why risk-aversion is so deeply embedded in our modern behaviour: Because the ones among our forebears who preferred the riskier hunter-gatherer model, well ... died.

Yuval Noah Harari, writer of Sapiens, Homo Deus, and 21 lessons for the 21st century said this happened because of the resurgence of cereals in the middle east due to the end of the ice age. In the beginning, wheat was one of the many foods we ate. But as humans had to move wheat from the place it grew in to their temporary settlement (caves etc), some of it inevitably fell and flourished. Over time, temporary outposts were built at the wheat sites for 2-3 months or so, to harvest and collect them. We learnt that wheat grew better if the soil was plowed. We did that since we thought it would give us more food. Slowly, one step after another, we settled down, in the hopes of making our lives better, but ultimately, we made it worse(until the Industrial Revolution 300 years ago, atleast). Women who couldn't give birth to kids while hunting/gathering since they were always on the move and breast-milk was limited, now started popping out kids as helping hands in fields, weaning them on porridge and other cereals. Little did they notice that that meant the food/person would fall, and that the lack of balanced nutrient-rich food at such a young age caused a fall in health, immunity, and ultimately mortality. The Agricultural Revolution, at least until supplemented by the industrial one, was humanity's biggest tragedy.

As many have said too, life was also probably crappy being hunter gathers. You were always under threat from wild animals and unruly humans, meaning you were exposed to danger as we migrated. Same goes for food, during our hunter gather days were completely dependent on wild plants producing a enough for us (which was probably rare than many thing). While at the same time dependent on herds of wild animals, who's numbers grew and shrank from year to year. Essentially life as a hunter gather means a population is always under stress from one thing or another. So when agricultural started paying off, our ancestors saw it as gift from the Gods. Now a person can work their own fields and produce their own food. No longer were they slaves to wild plants and later no longer slaves to wild herds, as raising livestock be came a thing. Something fundamental to human physiology then as today, humans will endure a lot as long as they feel they have a choice in the matter.

You are smart but also dumb. Two words: Food security. Thats the reason we adopted agriculture. When you have a choice between "Know where to get food" vs "Dont know" you choose the safer bet. The other activities certainly did happen but they were not the reason for choosing "the grind ahead of the "freedom" of living off the land". Once we figured out plants could be kept in a place and grown, it was just a matter of time before figuring out doing the same thing to the meat was also an advantage not to be passed up. Again, people certainly did other things besides this but those activities were only related to our food choices by way of frequency and specialization, not food source preference. Yes hunting and fishing remained but again, a skill you develop that feeds you that you can always fall back to agriculture when you fail at, is one you can afford to keep especially when it overlaps with some relevant skills of war back then. The transition from hunting gathering to agriculture is analogous to natural selection in the evolution theory. Despite many significant drawbacks (e.g. lower food diversity, more intense labor, higher mortality rate), agriculture simply produces more food and thus feed more people. When a tribe adopt agriculture, their population grows faster than those don't. A larger population makes them more robust against natural disasters and social conflicts. Over time, they out lived those who maintained hunting gathering.

Wanted to add on one reason why we transitioned from hunter gatherers to farmers: According to the book Sapiens, the transition was inevitable, because farms allowed for breeding of a larger population; though each individual lived poorer lives, but there were a larger number of people. And large number civilisations always won, whether in terms of fighting, or defending their territory. Farms also allowed specialisation, i.e. one farmer grows one type of crop and becomes an expert, and can feed the entire village. This allowed for scalability, because a farmer can grow for 10 people, but he can also grow for 100, as he could harness 'technology' (i.e. animals, and farm tools). Farms formed villages which allowed for a complex civilisation, i.e. where there is a leadership structure, and segregated roles. This would always win out over nomadic tribes, because villages could grow to cities, but nomadic tribes cannot scale past certain numbers, because they are groups that are constantly on the move, and their numbers are kept small, and when numbers are small, there is inability for a complex civilisation to form.

The people who lived back then had to deal with loss and tragedy very frequently.
If you sat down and talked with one of them you’d quickly find that they are not like us at all.
Death was constant, ancient people would reach adulthood by 16 then get married soon after. If you lived till 40 you were the village elder, life was tough as hell.
They fixed medical problems with very little to numb the pain. They warred with one another for resources, killing was part and parcel of life. If the group wasn’t hunting and expanding they were at a disadvantage to other tribes.
The modern man has a very easy life compared to the ancient man. They had to be a whole lot tougher than we are today.

We have a totally alien world in comparison to theirs. We’ve got set rules and legislation that keep society in order. They did not, who’s going to stop one tribe from massacring another?

Life was not easy, it was not nice or kind, it was mostly pain and brutality, where the strong survived and the weak died. We have very very nice lives today.

The main reason early agriculturalists dominated is probably a macabre game of numbers. Even though their lifestyle was harsher, it quite simply made more of them with ever more sophisticated tools and weapons, made possible as their large populations produced more specialists, and the more of them there were, the more land they needed to sustain themselves, and the more they would then take from the hunter gatherers. While we are fortunate enough now to live in an age in which living standards have improved again, it certainly gives one pause.

Indeed, for thousands of years people lived in tribes and small settlements, as you said, lived and did not grieve, people are the same as we are now. Then there were cities, there were those who said how to work (the minorities, lazy power-hungry owners) and the majority (who worked hard in the fields, because they had no choice). No person in their right mind would go for this on their own, there are only two options and they are not particularly different: A highly developed civilization, which either benefited from our development (for their own profit), or they thought it was better for us to become A Civilization - a progressorship. My believe is that human didn't domesticate wheat, wheat domesticated human.
After the first deliberate choice of switching to wheat as a more reliable food source over hunting, wheat drastically changed human diet from a protein main diet to a carbohydrate main diet. The food source also changed the breeding habit of human from only breeding in Spring to breeding whenever possible. And on top of all that, it changed human body to be more durable for field work than the old strength and nimble required for hunting.
All those change while wheat is just being wheat, they didn't have to change anything, and now they don't even have to worry about competition.

Are you going to talk about the "Younger Dryas"? I know it's controversial, but I think it very neatly explains why and how humans transitioned from hunter gathers to farmers at that specific time. So back some 12,900 years ago, there were large glaciers over Europe and North America. Something caused those glaciers to melt away within the time span of a few thousand years. Following that initial spark that caused the ice to start melting, the Earths temperature took a nose dive and dropped to full glacial conditions creating a winter for most of the planet that lasted over a thousand years. Sea levels rose some 400 feet (think of all the ice in Antarctica and Greenland, that's how much. This was certainly a transformative time in Human History that is not talked about much, the very definition of climate change. Nearly half of all mega-fauna went extinct, "American horses, sabertooths, lions, camels, giant sloths, cheetahs, dire wolves etc... I think it inconceivable for humans to have killed and made extinct all these animals, given their utility and our lower population. Most food would have been scarce coming out of this long winter. All these people living on the coastal cities would have been displaced, losing their homes, having to scavenge, centuries of failed crops due to the cold, losing some of their previous knowledge with successive generations in this long winter, eventually coalescing to create great coastal cities once again when the winter finally ended.

Thousands of years from now, if we may be as unfortunate as our past ancestors, there will be hardly a trace of many of our current coastal cities, Los Angeles , New York City, Miami, London, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Tokyo, Wherever you may live on the coast etc... for they would be under the water and eroding away with hardly a trace of their visible existence, eventual being buried by sediment. Just as the Titanic is but a fragment of its former self, Future archeologists will not find these and they will be lost to time. I'm not saying that this will be caused by solely us, but I highlighting a very much forgotten part of our history, the "sinking" of our past coastlines.

comment_text: What does it mean to be human?

The year is 4000, a team of archaeologists and specialists are digging up a city from the 21st century that went underground. They go inside the first house they dig out and marvel at how it all looks, wondering how it would be like to live in that era. They found old-fashioned pots, pans, and an old-fashioned gas stove. "Wonderful." one of the archaeologists say. They go upstairs and dig even more.

Eventually they encounter the first room. They determined as belonging to a male in his youth. They scan around the room to see in person the art forms they've only read about. One of the team approaches a piece of paper attached to the wall with an image printed on it, surprisingly still intact. The image is of a woman, in a style they called animated form. "This must be aneem," said one of the archaeologists. "I think it's pronounced a-nim-ay," said the historian. They quarrel for a few minutes on how it was pronounced, while the others continue to look around.

One of the researchers looks under a bed, and finds a white plastic bottle with what appears to be pump on top, along with what appears to be a yellowish-black rock. The researcher picks it up, puts it close to their face and immediately puts it back down as the putrid scent of the rock reached the researcher's nostrils. "Phew! What was that?" said the researcher. "I wonder what strange rituals they performed with that mysterious rock," said the archaeologist. The archaeologist grabs it with tongs and puts it inside a sample bag. "There. We should get this back to the museum for analysis, and display. I'll gain galactic fame for discovering this one!"

Now imagine an ancient race of aliens has been observing us all along. An artificial intelligence that has probes in orbit and hidden spying apparatus on earth and that can nap for millennia until something new happens. Not interacting or interfering, just recording our history.
Until we become an interstellar civilization! Then we are gifted a complete record of our history.

Looking at this, the part in the beginning of how limited our exact understanding of the deep past of humanity reminds me of the Babylonian historian Berossus and the "history of the world" books he wrote - of which we only know of through references, the books themselves are lost. But the first book of three detailed the history from the first kings, or the creation of the world, to the Great Flood. A span of time reaching 432,000 years.
Imagine if we had that book today. It could have been mostly myth, legends and made-up, but even legends and myths have some origins, and even having that available to us would be an invaluable resource. And imagine even if only 1% of that time he catalogued was true, that would mean an entire historical account would be available to us that is just as long as the Old Testament, but 100% accurate.

As a human biologist, I think its astonishing how the emergence of human civilizations shaped our DNA. For example, humans (just like other mammals) used to be lactose intolerant upon adolescence. However, the domestication of animals led to the regular consumption of milk about 20000 ago. At that time, a mutation occurred which made people lactose tolerant. This mutation was so beneficial during periods of starvation that it quickly became very common. Today, the majority of people with European descent is lactose tolerant (I made a video about this). I think human civilization is more complicated than that.  We recognize civilization springing up out of 4 river valleys at about the same time - the Indus, Nile, Yellow, and Tigris/Euphates.  Why at the same time?  Because Noah's flood of 4000 BC nearly wiped us out, but the survivors all had a history of civilization.  I think the Sphinx and the pyramids are at least 10,000 years old.  The Sphinx has water erosion from rainfall, and it was 10,000 years ago the last time it rained.  I think these and many other ancient ruins were built by the Clovis people, who disappeared about 12,000 years ago, possibly due to the huge meteor that hit southern Greenland about that time.  There have been lots of artifacts that date to impossibly old times based on carbon-dating, but these artifacts are usually ignored if it doesn't fit the narrative of civilization starting up at about 4000 B.C.  Popol Vuh talks about mankind being destroyed and reset several times.  The Egyptian priests told Solon that they had records of existential events that preceded Noah's flood. Quite a good video, though I have a minor gripe. The presentation of society evolving in a linear way, from hunter-gatherers to nomadic herders to sedentary agriculturalists, I think is a misrepresentation and oversimplification of nomadic societies on a few levels. I'll use Central Asia as an example.

Firstly, the distinction between nomadic herding societies and sedentary agricultural societies is less binary and clear-cut than frequently assumed. In Central Asia, steppe nomads would often only live in a nomadic, traveling lifestyle for part of the year, residing in mountain valley villages when conditions are less suited for grazing. In this way, nomadism can be seen as an ecological adaptation, rather than a stage in a linear societal evolutionary process. Peoples in regions where the terrain is suited for grazing animals often oscillate between living in semi-permanent settlements and moving along grazing routes. Of course, this kind of lifestyle-switching is less viable in the modern world, but nomadic herding societies still exist today, residing at times in modern cities and at times on the move. The existence of cities weakened but did not completely eliminate the ecological niche of nomadism, even in the modern age.

Secondly, nomadic and sedentary societies were not segregated, but rather coexisted and frequently interacted in mutually beneficial ways. Although agricultural towns have an absolute advantage in the production of goods over nomads, nonetheless herders maintained comparative advantage in many goods, especially those related to animal husbandry. In fact, many Central Asian settlements from the Bronze Age into the early Modern Era specialized in producing goods catering to nomads. One notable example is the oasis region of Khorezm, which served as the major gateway between the sedentary societies of the Middle East and nomadic fur traders of the Urals in the vital North-South fur route. In Khorezm, a major industry was silversmithing, since silver objects were frequently used as high-value currency for the northern nomads. This is how Sasanian silver was found in the Ural Mountains, and demonstrate how settlements at the edges of ecologies benefitted and benefitted from both sedentary and nomadic communities. It was certainly a two-way street.

Most importantly, the portrayal of nomadic society as a stepping stone towards a more 'civilized' sedentary agricultural society denigrates the cultures and customs of nomads. This is not to put the blame on Kurzgesagt; in fact, I think they handled the portrayal of the people in nomadic societies quite respectfully. I'm not blind to the central guiding theme in the video of people remaining largely the same even as society evolves. Still, the framing of the presentation matters, and in most media portraying the evolution of society over time, nomads are inevitably portrayed as a transitory phrase of human existence, a footnote on the path towards human flourishing. Certainly, there are definitions of civilization for which nomadic societies contributed little of note. Nomads didn't invent penicillin, computers, or nuclear weapons. They didn't discover black holes and supernovas, they didn't produce opera and novels, they didn't invent automobiles and political theories. Nonetheless, in cultural richness and sophistication nomadic societies are by no means the leaders of their sedentary counterparts. They produced beautiful and inspiring art, engaged in commerce and innovation, created complex social structures, and even founded empires. The stirrups seem inconsequential today, but they revolutionized warfare and communications, and enabled the rise of vast contiguous land empires, and this history-changing device was invented not by city dwellers but by nomadic herders. The largest land empire in history was not founded by the sophisticated civilizations of Rome and Xi'an, but by the steppe warriors of Karakorum. Is it any wonder that the societies of dynastic China and Turkic nomads beyond the border regions rose and fell simultaneously? Certainly the nomads prospered with trade with and raids upon the agricultural settlements—but we should not forget that the external threats of invasion and the opportunities of commerce with nomads also helped sedentary communities to organize into larger societal units.

This is again not a knock against Kurzgesagt and the new video, which I thought was on the whole excellent. I just hope this can serve as a reminder and a celebration of the great and unexpected diversity of humanity. Cheers!

It is interesting to contrast the sentiment expressed in this video with the arguments in the book Humankind: A Hopeful History by Rutger Bregman. Where as in this video, the invention of agriculture was presented as a great achievement, Bregman argues that it might have been a terrible mistake (at least for the first 11,800 years or so).

Agriculture created scarcity and the ability to concentrate property in the hands of the few. It created the conditions for the great ancient empires with their enslavement of large parts of humanity. It may have also led to the subjugation of women under patriarchy. This video leaves out any discussion of war. Archeologists think that large scale war was almost entirely absent from pre-agrarian societies. Almost none of the human remains from pre-historical times have injuries that were not caused by animals, and there are no cave paintings of human on human violence (but lots of paintings of using weapons to hunt animals).

For most of the agricultural era the vast majority of humans were poor serfs or outright slaves. Only in the last couple centuries has civilization provided any benefits to the common person. All this is not to say that we can or should go back to a hunter gather lifestyle today. Clearly, we can only move forward, but it's worth thinking about how many of things we take for granted as "progress" and "civilization" are actually detrimental to human freedom and wellbeing.

Curious that in my reflections I always tell myself that we will not take a big step as a species, until we unite, not as citizens of a country, a culture or a region of the world, believing that for those things we are still better or superior. But rather by recognizing and uniting ourselves for the only thing that unites us and makes us equal... To be human beings and to use the tools that represents our species to control to some extent our planet: Control and improvement of language, creativity, lifestyle and thinking.

Until we globally recognize our weaknesses as animals that we are, stop believing and create stupid differences, such as skin color, speech, culture, politics and religion, and focus In a more united and homogeneous future, I don't think we will take that big step as a species again.

And we will, the problem is when? 1000 years seems like a long time, for some animals like us that only live 100 at most, but for the universe and this planet, It is insignificantly fast, and many natural or socio-cultural and political threats can threaten the existence of our species.

So sometimes I think we don't have to leave all this to the next generations and they in turn to the next, taking small steps every 50 or 100 years or more... We have to be more aware, quick and committed to our species and future if we want to survive in an honest and dignified way and not be remembered, (if only a few survive to restart the human age In the case of any possibility of extinction), as a bad example and a disgrace for almost bearing the species to extinction.

Actually, future archeologists, be they human or otherwise, will dig up the ground, only to discover a thin black line.  That is all we amount to. To be a thicker black line we would have to be around for hundreds of millions of years as we are today.  And that just simply isn't going to happen.  One way or the other we will stop that from happening. The transition of hunter gatherers to farmers can be thought of in evolutionary terms. The farming societies had a more stable food source and could support a larger number of members. Because of this, it was easier for their society to grow and "reproduce" by taking over new lands (which they needed to grow more crops). All else being equal, societies which could grow their own food instead of relying on finding their next meal have a higher evolutionary fitness. I think to call the switch from nomads to farmers a deliberate choice made in thousands of individual societies is misleading, because there may have been other thousands of societies that chose to remain nomadic. They would have been much smaller and wouldn't have lived in concentrated areas that we would now call archeological sites, so we would know very little about them. The fact that we see very little nomadic societies today doesn't mean that they all decided to switch. It shows that, at the time of the split, being able to farm your own food led to higher fitness than having to find it.

It remains to be seen if we are actually better off for farming in the long run. It has created a world full of hedonistic pleasures where people are as unhappy as ever, a world with the largest human population ever recorded yet people feel more lonely than ever, a world where the main focus is to collect as much green paper as possible before you kick the bucket.

comment_by: George L Rockwell of The Northern Order
comment_text: The Industrial Revolution and its consequences have been a disaster for the human race. They have greatly increased the life-expectancy of those of us who live in “advanced” countries, but they have destabilized society, have made life unfulfilling, have subjected human beings to indignities, have led to widespread psychological suffering (in the Third World to physical suffering as well) and have inflicted severe damage on the natural world. The continued development of technology will worsen the situation. It will certainly subject human being to greater indignities and inflict greater damage on the natural world, it will probably lead to greater social disruption and psychological suffering, and it may lead to increased physical suffering even in “advanced” countries. The industrial-technological system may survive or it may break down. If it survives, it MAY eventually achieve a low level of physical and psychological suffering, but only after passing through a long and very painful period of adjustment and only at the cost of permanently reducing human beings and many other living organisms to engineered products and mere cogs in the social machine. Furthermore, if the system survives, the consequences will be inevitable: There is no way of reforming or modifying the system so as to prevent it from depriving people of dignity and autonomy. If the system breaks down the consequences will still be very painful. But the bigger the system grows the more disastrous the results of its breakdown will be, so if it is to break down it had best break down sooner rather than later. We therefore advocate a revolution against the industrial system. This revolution may or may not make use of violence; it may be sudden or it may be a relatively gradual process spanning a few decades. We can’t predict any of that. But we do outline in a very general way the measures that those who hate the industrial system should take in order to prepare the way for a revolution against that form of society. This is not to be a POLITICAL revolution. Its object will be to overthrow not governments but the economic and technological basis of the present society. In this article we give attention to only some of the negative developments that have grown out of the industrial-technological system. Other such developments we mention only briefly or ignore altogether. This does not mean that we regard these other developments as unimportant. For practical reasons we have to confine our discussion to areas that have received insufficient public attention or in which we have something new to say. For example, since there are well-developed environmental and wilderness movements, we have written very little about environmental degradation or the destruction of wild nature, even though we consider these to be highly important.

Basically we did not leave willingly the foraging live style for the agricultural and settled livestyle. Agriculture was at first a complement to hunting, then when they expanded it they obviously could not continue to hunt as much as before especially with population growing, then after several generations they were stuck with this new lifestyle that made us grow but also made us miserable. It was impossible to go back to foraging, not only was it not sustainable but also the skills for it were lost and would need to be reinvented. I find it interesting that a lot of us chose pastoralism though, I don't think we talk enough about it.

It is a paradox of our evolution, the way forward to progress was not the way towards happiness.

My personal theory about why they decided to shift from hunting and gathering to farming is because of disability. We have evidence that ancient humans as far back as the Neanderthals cared for the old and injured. I reason that farming began either as an accident or by observing how squirrels plant trees, and then the skill was experimented with by the elderly and the physically disabled since a small garden is a lot less physically demanding, but still provides some gains. Add time and the process improves until there is a paradigm shift where you have more guaranteed results than sending out a hunting party.

A major factor that lead to the agricultural revolution was competition with various species of herbivores and predators. Having fields you grow nearby guaranteed that you were more likely to eat more regularly, even if the overall diet was less nutritious, eventually members of the species that humans liked to eat didn't run away from us and in many cases actually came towards us for various reasons(access to more abundant food, protection from predators, etc...) and we wound up domesticating them which in turn gave us even more access to available food. In short, hunter/gatherers would have had a more nutritious diet, but they would have eaten less often. Mind you, there are way more factors than just that.

I must be insane. But I don’t feel any sense of pride watching this video. Just... fear. Fear that we’ll colonize another planet an ruin it as we’ve ruined this one. Watching this video just makes me wish that we had stayed in the wild, staying in packs and hunting animals. We deal with so many modern stressors that no other animal will ever deal with. Why do we put ourselves under constant stress, dealing with bills, work, school, other responsibilities? Wouldn’t it be easier to live the way that we were always intended to live, as wild animals, co-existing with other animals and hunting/gathering for our groups? In the wild, we would have other things to deal with, and we would still have stress. We would still have to work for food (like hunting and gathering and creating tools), we would still have to take care of family, and we would have to defend ourselves from other animals. But we wouldn’t be put on by constant unnatural stress like we are in current society.

I fear what’s in the future. I hope in 12,000 years we’re not living on another planet, as that means we’ve probably nearly or completely destroyed Earth by then. And then... once we colonize another planet, we’ll just destroy it like this we have this world. Because we’re selfish like that. We see human progress as great, wonderful, amazing. And sure, it’s great... for us. But human progress destroys our natural world. We refuse to coexist alongside nature and instead seek to destroy it for our own selfish gain. We’ve already polluted the Earth, I don’t want to see us pollute space (more than we already have) and other planets.

What positive things have humans even done? The only positive things I see us doing is attempting to reverse the damage we’ve caused to our own planet. Yeah sure, we’re intelligent, and our intelligence is impressive. But our intelligence causes living things to suffer and be destroyed... and it causes suffering for our own species, as we’re all forced to live in society with all these unnatural stressors.

I’m not a hippy, nor do I care if people chose to eat animals, as our species is meant to eat meat. But life is a beautiful scientific phenomenon... and all we do is destroy it in unnaturally high numbers. We’ve caused so many species to go extinct and we’ve caused several areas of the planet to just become barren. Areas that were once teeming with life are now just covered in buildings, human settlements, sometimes just dirt. I just don’t want life on this planet to go extinct because we were too selfish to live alongside it.

What good qualities do humans have other than their intelligence? And even our intelligence as a good quality is debatable, because our intelligence causes our species to believe we’re above all other life, which helps us justify our actions. Even if most life can not match our intelligence, that doesn’t make them any less beautiful. The very fact that life even exists as a phenomenon is amazing.

Seriously though - tell me one good thing humans have done that wasn’t directed at our species, tell me something we’ve done that wasn’t an attempt to reverse the damage we’ve caused the earth. Tell me something we’ve done that wasn’t done selfishly to help or advance our own species, and something that was done to benefit the Earth. I’m losing faith in our species and every day I hate being alive because of the species I was born as. I struggle to find any good qualities about our species and just see us as a pest, a parasite sucking up the resources on this planet and killing it. Our hyper intelligence was a mistake by nature and should have never happened.

If anybody read this far, I thank you. I know this was a rant and I probably seemed insane writing this. Just... thank you to anybody who listened. To be clear, I don’t hate anybody as an individual. I only hate our species as a whole and what we’ve done. Individually we can be good, and most of us mean no harm. As a species though we are nothing but trouble to this Earth.

I disagree strongly with this channel's view of the shift from hunter-gatherer to farmer/technology.
--These technological shifts were things like 20,000 years between slight improvements in spear/arrowheads. Then in less than a century there were cities, farming, metallurgy. The first cities were planned. How did a hunter-gatherer tribe of 'several dozen individuals' suddenly go "Ok - we make city for several thousand people. Farms with irrigation. Plan this out so we don't end up in a jumble downtown..." - note real cities of more recent history started and grew along coasts, rivers, trade routes - then when they became the seat of empires they had internal traffic/garbage, etc. problems. Rome. London. So when they became empires their new cities were planned. Like the very first cities...
--I suggest pursuing Donnely "Atlantis: The Antedilluvian World" - no "Pyramid hat" he went all over the world and compared different mythologies including non-western, non-christian based. And found tales all over of a golden age, men/gods from the sky giving man gifts/technology, an older world that was evil destroyed by a FLOOD... Not going to go "Jack Chick" on you, rather the end of the last ice age waters rose very quickly, that wiped out this earlier world civilization/s that likely were jump-started by extraterrestrials. The remnants regressed with their knowledge becoming myth and mystery, then recovered into our modern world eventually. But we were uplifted long ago, living as an animal like a pack of dogs with tools for near one million years first.

Worlds apart. Imagine being told of a keyboard and computer monitor when Augmented or Virtual Reality control of electronics has been the standard for five thousand years already xD

Call me short-sighted, but I find it impossible to believe we will develop even further as a species. Sure, we'll keep reproducing and try to find ways to improve our energy generation by the use of solar panels, windmills and nuclear reactors. But haven't we reached the limits in terms of what we can achieve? Why are we trying to escape the most human-friendly piece of material floating in space (Kurzgesagt's logo)? Our never-ending desire for progress might provide us with a slow but disheartening decline of our quality of life. And no one is capable of stopping it, because convenience serves man and the majority of people rather live in ignorance.

- The grass is always greener on the other side of the fence, until there is no grass left.

At some point, I hope this channel will explore the global cataclysm 12,900 years ago which nearly destroyed entire humanity. That is the event on which all of the global flood legends (Noah's Ark included) are based on. Something terrible happened then which nearly wiped us all out, and the event was imprinted on humanity's collective memory all around the world, because it's effects were global and felt everywhere. That is why stories of massive floods exist in many cultures. Many theorize it was a massive comet impact, which is referred to as Younger Dryas Impact Hypothesis.

It's also suggested that there existed a high civilization, which was utterly wiped out in this disaster. Plato's story of Atlantis is based on that society, and the inspiration for it came from a story passed down by countless generations when a city was submerged under water in a disaster. The timeframe of that event in the stories coincides exactly with the Younger Dryas event.

The events of THIS VIDEO take place AFTER that cataclysm, and these people are the descendats of those survivors. For roughly a thousand years after the disaster, Earth was a hostile landscape which was recovering from a global incineration and flooding, when Earth was literally on fire.

We know so little about our past, and we think all that existed before was hunter gatherers, but in reality the truth is way more complex than that. There existed developed civilizations in the past, and we are not the first. They might not have been as advanced as us, but human culture was more complex than we realize, and it was all wiped out essentially in one single day.

I must say I was disappointed with the video. Mainly because the script is wrong.

The first mistake is clearly the absolute glorification of nature and the hunter-gatherer life. Nature is ruthless and spares no pity to no one. The life of a hunter-gatherer is no different from the life of an animal. It's horrible. Very easy to die, if you are sick or injured you can't hunt nor gather and you just die at the spot from hunger, if you are lucky and don't become pray yourself.

So I say YES the transition to agriculture was a decision but for pretty obvious reasons. Because it really had no disadvantage over hunter-gatherers. It was a safer and easier life. Farming actually gives more food for less work than walking the forest all day to find nothing. So at the end. Farmers were more free than hunter-gatherers. Because really... Are you free if all you do is walk non-stop to the next area, pushed by the seasons, forced to wander around all day long just to survive?

I also don't buy that agriculture reduced the diet variety. Just my grandfather still remembers a lot of wild plants and animals that were eaten before. Farmers kept eating the same things as before, but of course the crops became dominant in the diet. Mainly because they now had more food. They could eat more. Not to mention that the crops and cattle were far more easy to digest than the wild plants and animals, and thus, more nutritious.

Also... What makes you all think that the agricultural transition was peaceful? I imagine there were a lot of disputes between tribes that kept being nomads, and those that settled on the land. They were competing for the same resources. And it's pretty easy to imagine nomads stealing crops from the farmers, and the farmers responding violently to protect their farm. Since... you know... A bad yield could mean starvation... and the stolen crop the difference between life and death for members of the family. But of course for the nomads, the stealing would save some of theirs...

I'm sure it was a pretty messy time. Just like the conquest of North America but worse. Worse because at the time the nomads and the farmers were on equal ground in terms of warfare.

Love these videos and always enjoy watching them, they're so well-made! But this video presents a common narrative where we used to be hunter-gatherers, then we became agriculturalists (and then industrial revolution, internet, etc.). In a sense this is obviously true, but all stages of human history can still be seen on Earth today. There are still hunter-gatherers! (And even though I have a smartphone, there are others who live in non-industrial societies, etc.). There's an incredible continuity of the hunter-gatherer lifestyle, from hundreds of thousands of years ago until today in 2020. Let's not treat these as linearly ordered, non-overlapping phases of history.

Humanity has seen many revolutionary developments, and I think agriculture is probably the most significant one (though of course it took place over many, many thousands of years!). And even modern hunter-gatherers interact with agricultural societies, so their lives are also affected. But a calendar which treats agriculture as defining the 'human era' feels like it's missing much not just of human history, but of how humans live *today*.

The history of humanity is one of incredible diversity, where people who have stood on the Moon co-exist with people who have never grown crops. Let's stop treating early history and pre-history exclusively as things of the past, and realize that they exist on Earth today! Let's celebrate that enormous diversity, and continuity across over 100,000 years, instead of saying humanity only 'really' got going 12,000 years ago.

I love all of your videos but I love this one the most. This is the kind of thing that is so helpful today. Nowadays it's a pretty popular opinion that mankind is a sad plague upon the world, the "humanity sucks" sentiment. But realistically its just not inaccurate. We have countless black marks on our history, yes, but we are also the dominant species on the planet and even the 2nd and 3rd best don't even come close to what we've done in just a few thousand years. Humanity has SO much potential. We've gone from hunter gatherers to farmers to astronauts to particle physicists. We survived the Toba supervolcano, the ice age, basically got so damn powerful in warfare that its been all but entirely deincentivized, took flight without wings, left the planet, landed on the moon, and invented a means by which to connect our entire species globally through near instant communication. And truthfully, we've barely even begun as a species. Even when we screw up astronomically we can and do fix it, and we have the potential to do it again and again. I love videos like this because they're a reminder to everyone that believes humanity is a lost cause, that no, that couldn't be further from the truth. We CAN make it, because we've done it before.

2,000,000 years of human history and only in the last 20,000 years did we figure out how to live in communities, towns and cities? Just because there's no evidence of how humans lived in that humongous amount of time, doesn't mean they were only hunter-gatherers up until 20,000 years ago. That just means anything could be possible. I think we're pushing society into this 'mainstream' historical narrative too much. We should all be a little more open-minded about our ancient history.

For instance: evidence shows that the Sphinx (which was carved out of the bedrock of the Giza plateau) sustained heavy rain damage, from years and years of heavy rainfall. The last time this would have been possible in that area was ~12,000 years ago, in an era historians call 'the Younger Dryas'. This means that the Sphinx must have already been built back then. Yet Egyptologists claim it was built by the dynastic Egyptians around 2,500 B.C., pushing the world into this narrative which has now been proven to be false. Scientifically proven, not by those narrow-minded Egyptologists.

"The Agricultural Revolution certainly enlarged the sum total of food at the disposal of humankind, but the extra food did not translate into a better diet or more leisure. Rather, it translated into population explosions and pampered elites. The average farmer worked harder than the average forager and got a worse diet in return.

The Agricultural Revolution was history’s biggest fraud. Who was responsible? Neither kings, nor priests, nor merchants. The culprits were a handful of plant species, including wheat, rice, and potatoes. These plants domesticated Homo sapiens, rather than vice versa.” - Yuval Noah Harari, ‘Sapiens’, Chapter 5.

Harari's stance on the Agricultural Revolution is quite interesting, he surely surprised me.
I think some of his points actually do make sense, like the ones about a limited variety of diet. But I don't think Humans remaining hunters and gatherers was an option. Coming together, settling in a place and expanding, is ultimately progress.

What would the Human civilization look like without the Agricultural revolution?
I think we would have remained the way we did for 2 million years before the revolution. My thoughts on this subject are evolving and would appreciate your response :)
