If you think the world is weird and confusing now: imagine being born in 1900.

When you're 1 year old, Australia is colonised and the first transatlantic radio signal makes its way to its destination.

When you're 2, Cuba gains independence.

When you're 3, the first controlled heavier-than-air flight is successful.

When you're 5, Russia has a revolution and overthrows its autocracy.

When you're 8, cars suddenly become extremely affordable.

When you're 12, the Chinese Empire collapses into a republic.

When you're 14, a war begins: the biggest war in human history. It will not end until you are 18.

When you reach 18, a deadly pandemic sweeps across the world, infecting over a third of the world's population. Almost every press in the world censors discussion about it. Meanwhile, empires, the hearts of civilisation, are collapsing left and right and states are declaring independence throughout the world.

When you are 19, the borders of Europe are redrawn. The League of Nations, an international coalition like nothing ever seen before, is founded. Germany collapses and is rebuilt into a prosperous republic. The proton is discovered.

When you are 20, prohibition begins in the US. Palestine is established by the UK. A strange old man named Gandhi is shaking things up in India.

When you're 21, Germany's economy is put under strain by aggressive demands for reparations from the Great War that it is impossible for them to repay. Extremism is on the rise.

When you're 22, Italy attempts to reconquer Libya. A major international union collapses in Central America, and a march on Rome brings a new type of government to power, one driven by a cult of personality. The President of Poland is assassinated.

When you're 23, a new currency has to be introduced to counteract the hyperinflation in Germany. There is a failed attempt to overthrow the government there by a group calling themselves the National Socialists. The President of the US dies just two years into his term and has to be replaced by the Vice President.

When you're 24, Vladimir Lenin dies. Russia is dropped into a brutal power struggle between Trotsky and Stalin, both of whom have extremely different ideals to Lenin. The FBI is established, and a law is established in the US to ban immigration from Asia in order to preserve American culture and standing by reducing the number of non-white people coming in - there is almost no opposition to this from anyone in Congress.

When you are 25, Italy becomes a dictatorship. A book written by the leader of the German National Socialist Party while he was imprisoned is published, outlining a model for dictatorships of the future. This becomes known the same name as the Italian party in power: fascism. At the same time, the first televisual image is invented.

When you are 26, countries left and right are being replaced by dictatorships: Greece, Portugal, and Poland.

When you are 27, Stalin wins the power struggle. A civil war begins in China. A school is blown up, killing dozens of young children and their teachers in Michigan. Ireland splits in two, and around two thirds of it leaves the United Kingdom. The first non-stop flight from New York to Paris is successful.

When you are 28, Mickey Mouse first appears. Penicillin and bubblegum are a thing now. These damn kids need something better to worry about.

When you are 29, the greatest economic collapse in history begins. It will not let up until you are 33. By the time it has, the so-called Nazis are in power in Germany.

Abyssinia is conquered by Italy when you are 35. Next year, the Spanish Civil War will begin, and the Great Purge will be started by Stalin.

That's the first third of the 20th century. You probably know the rest. It doesn't let up for a long time, and you're 89 when the Berlin Wall falls. When you're 91, the Soviet Union falls.

Life is confusing and bad things happen a lot. But no matter how bad it feels, we were still born into a good era. As we get bigger, our problems do too. But remember: we started the 20th century without knowing how to fly and we were on the Moon 65 years after the Wright Brothers. Geopolitics is scary. Wars and pandemics are awful. But it's important not to blink and let the best parts of history pass you by. 2020 is stressful, but just you wait. We aren't even a quarter of the way into this century yet.

It's worth noting that the transition to agriculture may have been coercive in many cases. Grain can be measured, stored, and taxed, allowing a ruling class to get nutrition without working the fields themselves. If I had to guess (and a guess is all I have anyway), I'd say the reason we chose agriculture over nomadic lifestyle is that we, generally speaking, like to put down roots.  We like to travel and visit but we always want to go home afterward; and home, being in the same place, is a comfort - desirable.  Building a house and raising a family further cements our concept of permanency as well.  Ironic, I suppose, given that same permanency is essentially the catalyst to our increasing anonymity.

Here is my philosophical input. People, such as myself, who live in first world postindustrial countries have completely and utterly transcended natural survival. Our food, water, and shelter is guaranteed and insured. We no longer need to deal with the problems associated with trying to survive naturally, instead, we need to survive artificially. Artificial survival is a process that has been in development since the dawn of civilization, and it is only in the 21st century when total artificial survival has become the mainstay way of life in most developed countries. This means that, with our basic life needs guaranteed, our concept of survival revolves around unnatural and artificial things we made, like money, social status, material possession, and philosophical motives (like a life goal). This is our survival now. People like to glorify natural survival as a harmless and good thing to do, and that human civilization has been a net negative to our species, but they suffer from the fallacy of thinking that just because something is natural it must mean it is good. Natural survival was just as stressful and hard as it is to artificially survive in today's world, we just stress about different things. Instead of stressing over how we will physically get our food, we are more concerned with the artificial monetary value of the food we are guaranteed to get. It is our goal as a species to transcend artificial survival one day, which would essentially be a utopia. A society where we live perfect lives untouched by hardship or any concept of survival. The second you are born, you are guaranteed everything. This is, of course, hypothetical, and I don't necessarily think that it is even possible to fully transcend artificial survival as an entire species.

"Our numbers would explode by orders of magnitude." Uhh definite nope on that one. Mars is physically smaller (and notably less habitable) than Earth, and we don't even have a third candidate planet for hosting human life. So our numbers could "explode" by significantly less than double for a mere interplanetary expansion. We'd have to go interstellar to even have a hope of population growth more than maybe double our current numbers.

And that's already assuming a fairly large Earth-bound growth rate (questionable due to sustainability issues and decreasing birth rates in developing nations,) plus fully colonizing Mars (even more questionable because we have no idea if that's even possible yet. We think it might be and hope that will be eventually, but we haven't put a single person on the surface yet never mind sustaining an entire population.)

I find it hard to believe that the transition from hunting and gathering to agriculture would have been completely voluntary even for the earliest adopters - in terms of quality of life and nutrition, sticking with hunting and gathering while only using rudimentary agriculture as a supplement would have obviously been preferable, but some sort of crisis, similar to the climate crisis we face now, would necessarily have compelled hunter-gatherers to fully invest in growing their own food using their pre-existing knowledge as a matter of survival. Relying on labor-intensive food sources like grains, eggs, or milk to feed yourself and your community isn't something that community would likely choose unless edible wild plants and animals suddenly became very scarce, for either climate change reasons or Malthusian ones. Just like the choice to slowly remove trophically-inefficient foods (meat, eggs, milk, etc.) from our diets isn't a choice many of us want to make, but may have to make to increase the Earth's carrying capacity and hit the brakes on climate change for the sake of our collective survival.

I understand the discovery and evolution of the Agriculture Lifestyle was slow but in my opinion it has an obvious an very positive feedback from converting to nomadic to a sedentary culture. Hunter-gatherers had the advantage of many more different food sources but that does not mean a vast Cornucopia of food and resources, usually the opposite. Covering a big area to feed also means face more different natural dangers (predators, bad weather, etc...). This video shows how HG planted food during their trips, and most likely some of these planted seeds were the most reliable food source they had so at the end is common sense to think they would rely more and more in planting seeds until stop being nomadic.

What if the decision to settle down and focus on agriculture was driven by warfare and territorial clashes? It's fairly obvious that the same amount of land at some point had to support a growing global population likely leading to a decrease in the land available for hunting and gathering for any one group. The only likely solutions are: increasing efficiency of existing land or acquiring more/better land. If you have good land then you'll want to defend it, which provides both the means and the reason to establish permanent or semi-permanent settlements to defend against others. This creates a positive feedback loop between settling down and developing agriculture,

Being a human biologist, I think its crazy how the emergence of human civilizations shaped our DNA as well. To give an example, humans (like many other mammals) used to be lactose intolerant upon adulthood. However, the domestication of animals led to the regular consumption of milk roughly 20000 ago. At that time, a mutation occurred which made people lactose tolerant and this mutation was so beneficial during periods of starvation that it soon spread across populations making the majority of people with European descent lactose tolerant today (I made a video about this). Human evolution is so fascinating!

I'm not a huge history buff, but I do always like to think about how all those ancient periods were still involving people - people that actually existed and lived at some point, and had whole lifetimes (though sometimes sadly short ones) of experiences. I have mundane days where I walk to where I get work done, and probably so did these people, but the sights and thoughts they experienced during their "commute" were so very different. And with the next generation, things will be different during their days, too - even if it's not as dramatic as ancient history to today.

I wonder how exciting it was back then to hear the news and idea that food could just be put in the ground, and with some patience and effort, more food would come back out. That someone had found out if you grind up all those crunchy grains into a powder and put it near fire, it produced a super-tasty and soft thing to eat. Nowadays I lazily raise eyebrows at the latest news about a new Hadron Collider experiment or how people are finding ways to turn plastic back into oil - back then, such news of innovation must have been utterly thrilling to hear.

I think the positive message you wanted to bring here is misleading and nefast for the explanation of the agricultural revolution.
Like you said in the video why should people who are litteraly living a certain way for thousands of years change that way of life? Especially when that way of life is not that bad. I find the argument that significantly lowering your standard of living, just to be togheter with more people, not convincing. It does not matter how 'good' you think people are, they will not want to give up their food and conforts, just to be togheter...
Another thing which is wrong in the video is that you seem to suggest that by the spreading of knowledge and the meeting of people the Agricultural Revolution came about. But it is proven that this revolution happenend in at least a dozen places on earth independent of eachother and on the same time! It is also proven that hunter gatherers knew how to cultivate crops, they probably did it on a limited scale, but they did not have to engage in agriculture because it was not (yet) necessary. There were animals and plant enough in 'nature'. The Agricultural Revolution was not a technological revolution!
A more convincing explanation I find in the concept of 'Population Pressure' (even if it is contested...). Due to a very slow, but steady increase in population, the food you want is becoming more and more scarce. So you can do two things; 1. eat something else, but people don't want to do that if they have to. You can try to go somewhere else, but eventually all places will be taken by other people. So 2. people start growing the food they want themselves, or they stay in a particular place were they know they are certain they will find their food. Population pressure is not when a particular area can not sustain X amount of people anymore, but it is when there are to many people in that area for them to continue living the way they were. So people HAD TO engage in agriculture, I don't think they really wanted to.
Source: Sanderson D., The Neolithic Revolution, in Social transformations. A general theory of historical development, Lanham: Rowan & Littlefield Publishers, 1999.

I am a sociologist. I love Kurzgesagt! Small correction at 4:46: it is not necessarily the case that 'pockets of knowledge expanded', depending on what is meant by it. Our ancestors had the same amount of knowledge as us on an individual level. They just knew more about their immediate environment, about plants, animals and nature in general. That insane amount of 'local knowledge' kept them alive as hunters/gatherers, which would be impossible for us if we went back in time. On a societal level, the accumulation of knowledge is of course true: we accumulated knowledge by our extraordinary capacity to learn socially. Social learning combined with language is what distincts us from other intelligent species. There is, however, a lot of knowledge that is gone forever so it is not just a cumulative process or a one way street. This process is continuous: a lot of languages are dying at this very moment, and with them the 'local knowledge' that accompanies those languages. Keep doing the great work!

It was never the settled agriculturalists that moved it was the nomads. Key example the indo-european invasions. The largely settled original europeans (cheddar man, etruscans and the basques) were virtually wiped out by the nomads, as seen in haplogroups. It is speculated that the concept of the earthmother is a remnant from the original europeans and the sky-father from the indo-europeans. The malnourishment of the settled tribe which only feeds on grain is the reason why the vikings, mongols, indoeuropeans, magyars and many more had the ability to invade as their diet had more animal protein and fat. I understood that the transition to agriculture can be considered more or less a trap: life in an agricultural society has several drawbacks (disease, boredom, being dependent on the success of a few crops, a less varied diet, to name a few) but because we were able to sustain a bigger population. So big that it would not be able to survive in a hunter gatherer setting, so doubling down on the agriculture thing was considered the only option. This meant that societies did transition from hunter gatherer to agricultural, but were rarely able to transition "back" to hunter gatherer.

The farming revolution wasn't a result of people sharing farming technology. It was a result of a single people migrating outwards and interbreeding with local paleolithic populations. Farming populations had a common origin, spoke the same language or family of languages, and shared common cultural and religious beliefs. Genetic, linguistic, and comparative religious studies all confirm this. The farming migration displaced paleolithic languages and cultures, and brought with them new genes, like the genes for light skin, which have been correlated with the transition to farming and diets low in vitamin D.

There are several other theories why agriculture spread. One is that people loved beer so much, that they were convinced to settle down to make more of it.
Another one is that settled people lived in larger communities that were able to defend against the nomads that were living in smaller groups and further apart. So agriculture was a military advantage. One compelling piece of evidence is that areas in which agriculture spread experienced dramatic shifts in the DNA of people living there. Humans that lived in central Europe before agriculture was known there were completely replaced by other people at the same time that agriculture spread there. So the farmers migrated to Europe and whiped out the local hunter gatherer population.

I'd like to point to a different reason why human decided to stop hunting and to practice agriculture. A slighty darker possibility.

Back in our early day, humans were fantastic stamina hunters, meaning the ywere excellent at hunting megafaune. Most of the small and rapid animal were harder to catch, while slow and large animal were easy and meant more meat. The mammoth was hunted down to extinction by humans.
And this is when we started using agriculture. Because we killed every megafaune in the nature. Because it was impossible to live just hunting. Maybe there were "faune change" people telling to stop overhunting and there were "faune change denier". The humanity cornered itself into agriculture.
And right now, we are doing it against. By overexploiting our environment, we are cornering ourselves into finding new solution. So far, it was green revolution that drastically improved the productivity of agriculture. We're falling in the same trap over and over again.
But the good new is, if humanity is terrible at avoiding trap, it's excellent at getting out of it. Hopefully, we'll find a way to fix the climate.

Just a quick correction: Vibrio cholerae is NOT a microorganism that is adapted to infect humans or survive in the human body. It is a symbiotic bacterium that helps certain crustaceans procreate and it can cause harm in the body, yet it is not intrinsic pathogenic.
Whats quite striking about a cholera infection is that it is extremely similar in every patient in terms of its progression and the best (and kind of only) treatment is to give the patient saltwater at a constant rate to replenish their fluid reserves. But it only takes three to four days for a cholera infection to be done with, which is remarkable, because there are virtually no harsh courses of the disease.
The bacterium doesn't even multiply inside the human body. It's just lost and causes harm accidentally because it is in an environment that it isn't adapted for.

One of the other hypotheses I had seen about what sparked civilization was that it was done out of desperation. If you look at where the first civilizations started, they are generally river valleys surrounded by vast desert. Once you found one of these areas and ate the food there, it would be very dangerous to leave, so you are forced to till the land to stay afloat.

And I suppose the fact that agriculture wasn't initially a very good tradeoff was probably nearly invisible at the time. You go from a few hours hunting and gathering, to a few +1 hours tilling crops as a supplement. A generation or so later this becomes 6 hours. Generations later it becomes 8, 10, 12, 16 hours during the season. But it would have been hard to notice within the generation. You would instead have your grandparents talk about how they worked slightly less and maybe had a fewer disease or two.

Comparing that to the pace of the industrial revolution, we now have youtube stars whose grandparents were farmers. The change per generation is WAY more drastic so things getting better or worse becomes way more obvious.

Specifically, studying archaeology has helped me cope by knowing humanity - and life in general - have been in tough spots like this many times before. Maybe only fragments will remain. Maybe there won’t be anything left that we could recognise. Perhaps, as I fear most, the world will do just well enough that it makes life wretched for anyone or anything left.

If I were to take a wild guess at why humans switched from hunting to farming, I'd guess that it has something to do with a risk/reward factor.
Crops can't run away or fight back, so weaker humans could be put to work and would be more likely to survive. On top of which, events where a person becomes too ill to hunt or simply got unlucky when hunting are significantly less likely to devastate individuals or even full tribes.

Moving around less also enables tribes to expand more rapidly and experiment with longer term and more permanent ideas, so maybe the humans of that age were just the earliest form of scientist.

And just as this comes out, I finish the last book in the series "Chronicles of Ancient Darkness", fantasy series about a boy, a wolf, and a girl in europe some 6000s years ago. The author, Michelle Paver did a lot of research about how humans lived in that time as well as what their culture and beliefs could have been.
It is pretty interesting, as they are never depicted as dumb or misinformed. Simply less knowledgeable about things like agriculture and had a different sets of beliefs tied to a hunter-gatherer living.

The story is decent, but the worldbuilding is where it really shines.

Years ago, the anthropologist Margaret Mead was asked by a student what she considered to be the first sign of civilization in a culture. The student expected Mead to talk about clay pots, tools for hunting, grinding-stones, or religious artifacts.

But no. Mead said that the first evidence of civilization was a 15,000 years old fractured femur found in an archaeological site. A femur is the longest bone in the body, linking hip to knee. In societies without the benefits of modern medicine, it takes about six weeks of rest for a fractured femur to heal. This particular bone had been broken and had healed.


Mead explained that in the animal kingdom, if you break your leg, you die. You cannot run from danger, you cannot drink or hunt for food. Wounded in this way, you are meat for your predators. No creature survives a broken leg long enough for the bone to heal. You are eaten first.

A broken femur that has healed is evidence that another person has taken time to stay with the fallen, has bound up the wound, has carried the person to safety and has tended them through recovery. A healed femur indicates that someone has helped a fellow human, rather than abandoning them to save their own life.

Our ancestors were just like us. We have ancient greek slingstones that have the word "Catch" and lightning bolts carved on the side, there are suits of medieval armor that have every known obscene gesture chiseled into their metal breastplates, there were dirty jokes, drunk wisemen, corrupt politicians, and of course storytellers.

Fun fact, one of the oldest jokes I've heard of is actually an ancient Greek tale about how Heracles had to rescue two Athenian princes from Hades' home after they went there to claim they had the right to sleep with his wife. Hades said they could do so once the meal was over and their butts left their seats. When the two princes tried to stand they found their butts had become stuck to the seats and could not move. When Heracles came and Hades explained the situation, Heracles grabbed each prince with a hand and ripped them off the chairs, but their butts were stuck there for all eternity... and that is why ancient Greeks believed men from Athens have no ass... Yep, ancient gay "you got no booty" joke. Life is a circle, humans are as wonderful as they were back then but we are more civilized in so many ways.
